Binomial distribution

Suppose we have n = 30 independent Bernoulli trials with p = 0.2.












The number of ‚Äúsuccesses‚Äù out of n independent Bernoulli trials with probability of success, p, follows a binomial distribution with parameters n and p.

title: Parametric distributions to describe and simulate data
text:
A Binomial random variable
X = X_1 + X_2 + \cdots + X_n \sim B(n, p)

X_i \sim \text{Bernoulli}(p) where p is the probability of success,
X_i = 1 if i-th trial is a success, otherwise X_i = 0,
all the trials are independent and p is constant for all trials,
X \in \{0, 1, \ldots, n\} is the number of successes out of n trials.





Expected value: E(X) = np
Variance: \text{Var}(X) = np(1-p)
Standard deviation: \text{SD}(X) = \sqrt{np(1-p)}




Probability mass function:
P(X = x) = \binom{n}{x} p^x (1-p)^{n-x}

Normal distribution


A continuous distribution that is symmetric and bell-shaped.
The probability density function is:

f(x; \mu, \sigma) = \frac{1}{\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}}\text{exp}\left(-\frac{(x - \mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}\right)




X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2) where

E(X) = \mu is the mean/expected value and
\text{Var}(X) = \sigma^2 is the variance.

The standard normal distribution is N(0, 1).

The t-distribution is used when the sample size is small and the population standard deviation is estimated from the sample.
The grey area is N(0, 1) for comparison.

A number of distribution in nature appears to conform a normal distribution (if you ignore the fact that some values can never be negative).

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Correlation coefficient

The sample Pearson correlation coefficient, denoted as r, is a measure of the strength of a linear relationship between two variables (x and y).

r = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n(x_i-\bar{x})(y_i - \bar{y})}{\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^n(x_i - \bar{x})^2\sum_{i=1}^n(y_i - \bar{y})^2}}

The correlation coefficient ranges from -1 to 1.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Simple linear regression

We seek to model the relationship between:

the mean of a response variable, y, and
a single explanatory variable (or predictor/covariate) x.

For observations i = 1, 2, \ldots, n:


y_i  = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_i + \epsilon_i



\boldsymbol{\beta} = \begin{bmatrix}\beta_0 \\ \beta_1\end{bmatrix} are referred to as the regression parameters/coefficients.

intercept slope error for the i-th observation, and assume \epsilon_i \sim NID(0, \sigma^2), i.e.¬†normally and independently distributed with mean 0 and variance \sigma^2.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Least Squares Estimates












Find \hat \beta_0 and \hat \beta_1 that minimize the sum of squares:

\text{RSS}(\beta_0, \beta_1) = \sum_{i=1}^n \left(y_i - (\beta_0 + \beta_1 x_i)\right)^2

The least squares estimates can be found by using calculus.
Visually, we can try changing the regression parameters below:

text:
Fitted values

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Making inferences


The standard deviation of an estimator is referred to as the standard error.
In making inferences, you may like to know:

what is the standard error of \hat{\beta}_1?
is \beta_1 \neq 0?
what is the confidence interval of the average y for a given x?
what is the prediction interval of y for a given x?

 It‚Äôs important to note that making inferences require the assumptions of the linear regression model to be satisfied.
So check model assumptions first!

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Assumptions for linear regression

Recall for i=1,\ldots,n, \epsilon_i \sim NID(0,\sigma^2) which means:

(A1) \text{E}(\epsilon_i) = 0
(A2) \epsilon_1, \ldots ,\epsilon_n are independent.
(A3) \text{Var}(\epsilon_i) = \sigma^2 which is called the homoscedasticity assumption.
(A4) \epsilon_1, \ldots ,\epsilon_n are normally distributed
(A5) the predictors are known without error.




An unbiased estimate of \sigma is given by:

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Checking assumptions

A1 is satisfied by definition for the least squares estimates.











A2 and A3 can be checked by plotting the residuals against the fitted values and ensuring that there is no pattern or trends.












Also checked by plotting the residuals against the predictor(s).












Sometimes plotting the residuals against the order of data entry can also be useful in identifying potential violations of A2.












A4 can be checked by plotting the normal quantile-quantile plot of the residuals. If it roughly straight then A4 is satisfied.










There are no standard ways to check A5 easily.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Influence measures

The data may contain outliers, high leverage values, and other unusual values that can affect the regression model.











Let‚Äôs check the ‚Äúinfluential‚Äù observations:












Red points are the observations to scrutinize further.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Hypothesis testing for regression parameters

Consider testing if the j-th regression parameter is significant for j = 1, \ldots, p = 2:

H_0: \beta_j = 0 \quad \text{vs} \quad H_A: \beta_j \neq 0

Assumption: suppose the residuals are normally distributed.
The test statistic and its distribution is

\dfrac{\hat{\beta}_j - \beta_j}{\text{SE}(\hat{\beta}_j)} \sim t_{n-p}.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Confidence interval for regression parameters

The 100(1-\alpha)\% confidence interval for the j-th regression parameter is

\hat{\beta}_j \pm t_{n-p, 1-\alpha/2} \times \text{SE}(\hat{\beta}_j).

For \alpha = 0.05, the 95% confidence interval for the regression parameters are:

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Is this coin unbiased?









Suppose I have a coin that I‚Äôm going to flip 
If the coin is unbiased, what is the probability it will show heads?
Yup, the probability should be 0.5.
So how would I test if a coin is biased or unbiased?
We‚Äôll collect some data.
Experiment 1: I flipped the coin 10 times and this is the result:





The result is 7 head and 3 tails. So 70% are heads.
Do you believe the coin is biased based on this data?

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Testing coin bias

Experiment 2: Suppose now I flip the coin 100 times and this is the outcome:



We observe 70 heads and 30 tails. So again 70% are heads.
Based on this data, do you think the coin is biased?

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Null hypothesis significance testing
Hypothesis and Assumptions

Suppose X is the number of heads out of n independent tosses.
Let p be the probability of getting a head for this coin.
Hypotheses: H_0: p = 0.5 vs.¬†H_A: p \neq 0.5

Assumptions: Each toss is independent with equal chance of getting a head.

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Null hypothesis significance testing
Test statistic, Verify and Conclusion

Test statistic: X \sim B(n, p). Recall E(X) = np. The observed test statistic is denoted x.
Verify: P-value P(\mid X - np\mid \geq \mid x - np\mid ), critical value or confidence interval
 Conclusion: Reject null hypothesis when the p-value is less than some significance level \alpha. Usually \alpha = 0.05.

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
HATPC
Hypothesis, Assumption, Test statistic, V-erify, Conclusion

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Binomial test (two-sided)
H_0: p = 0.5 vs.¬†H_A: p \neq 0.5
Assumption: each toss is independent with equal chance of getting a head.



Experiment 1

x = 7 heads, out of n = 10 tosses











The p-value is P(|X - 5| \geq 2) \approx 0.34



Experiment 2

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Binomial test (one-sided)
H_0: p = 0.5 vs.¬†H_A: p > 0.5








H_0: p = 0.5 vs.¬†H_A: p < 0.5

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
P-values

 Reject null hypothesis when the p-value is less than some significance level \alpha.
Usually \alpha = 0.05.
The p-value is the probability of observing a test statistic as extreme as the one observed, under the null hypothesis H_0.
If the p-value is small, it suggests that the observed data is unlikely to have occurred under the null hypothesis.
A high p-value suggests that the observed data is consistent with the null hypothesis, it doesn‚Äôt mean that the null hypothesis is true.

Popular misconception:

The p-value is not the probability that the null hypothesis is true or false.
Remember that NHST is a test of significance, not a test of acceptance or truth.

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Binomial proportion confidence interval

A confidence interval is a range of values that is likely to contain the true value of the parameter.


A (two-sided) 95% confidence interval for p (using Clopper and Pearson method) is given as:










If H_0: p = p_0 vs H_A: p \neq p_0 and the 100(1-\alpha)% confidence interval contains p_0, then we fail to reject the null hypothesis at \alpha significance level.
\alpha = 0.05 \rightarrow 95% confidence interval is a common choice.

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Power of a hypothesis test

The power of a test is the probability of rejecting H_0 when H_A is true.

























For H_0: p = 0.5 vs.¬†H_A: p \neq 0.5, if the number of trials is 5, then it doesn‚Äôt matter what your test statistic is, the p-value is always greater than 0.05!

 This means that this test has zero power.

 Judgement by p-value, critical value or confidence interval

title: Introduction to statistical inference
section: One-sample t-test: testing for the mean
text:
One-sample t-test: testing for the mean
H_0: \mu = \mu_0 vs.¬†H_A: \mu \neq \mu_0
Sample n times from a population with mean \mu.

Assumptions: Population data is normally distributed, or otherwise the sample size n is large.
Test statistic: t = \dfrac{\bar{X} - \mu_0}{S/\sqrt{n}} \sim t_{n-1}, where:

\bar{X} is the sample mean,
S is the sample standard deviation,
n is the sample size.

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
One-sample t-test: P-value

Verify: P-value = P(|t| \geq |t^*|)

title: Introduction to statistical inference
section: Two-sample t-test: testing for the difference in means
text:
Two-sample t-test: testing for the difference in means

Sample n_1 times from population 1 with mean \mu_1.
Sample n_2 times from population 2 with mean \mu_2.
Sampling from populations 1 and 2 should be independent.

H_0: \mu_1 = \mu_2 vs.¬†H_A: \mu_1 \neq \mu_2

Assumptions: Both populations are normally distributed (or sample sizes n_1 and n_2 are sufficiently large).
Test statistic: t = \dfrac{\bar{X}_1 - \bar{X}_2}{\sqrt{\dfrac{S_1^2}{n_1} + \dfrac{S_2^2}{n_2}}} \sim t_{n_1 + n_2 - 2}, where:

\bar{X}_i and S_i are the sample mean and standard deviation, respectively, of population i.

Verify: P-value = P(|t| \geq |t^*|)

title: Introduction to statistical inference
section: Paired t-test: testing for the difference in means
text:
Paired t-test: testing for the difference in means

Sample n times from a population with observation pairs.
d_i = X_{1i} - X_{2i} is the difference between the two observations in pair i. H_0: \mu_1 = \mu_2 vs.¬†H_A: \mu_1 \neq \mu_2 H_0: \mu_d = 0 vs.¬†H_A: \mu_d \neq 0
